skill.name: statsmodels
skill.description: Statistical models library for Python. Use when you need specific model classes (OLS, GLM, mixed models, ARIMA) with detailed diagnostics, residuals, and inference. Best for econometrics, time series, rigorous inference with coefficient tables. For guided statistical test selection with APA reporting use statistical-analysis.
skill.summary: Apply statistical models including OLS, GLM, time series, and discrete choice models with full diagnostics
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing markdown files with code examples. Static scanner flagged 415 alerts but all are false positives from scanning markdown documentation. No executable code exists. The skill is a pure reference guide for statsmodels library usage.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: 352x 'Ruby/shell backtick execution' in markdown code blocks
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Backticks are markdown syntax for code blocks. The flagged shell commands like `grep -r` are legitimate documentation examples showing search patterns, not actual shell execution.
HC2 and HC3 refer to Heteroskedasticity-Consistent standard error types in statistics, not command-and-control malware indicators.
No cryptographic code exists. This is a statistics documentation skill. Scanner produced false positives on unrelated text patterns.
These are legitimate matplotlib plotting calls: ax1.set_title('ACF') - standard charting code, not dynamic function construction.
grep commands in documentation are examples showing how to search the documentation files, not reconnaissance activity.
Scanner flagged false positives; no actual import() expressions exist in the documentation.

content.value_statement: Perform rigorous statistical analysis using OLS, GLM, ARIMA, and discrete choice models. Get publication-ready results with full diagnostics, coefficient tables, and residual analysis.
actual_capabilities: Fit OLS, WLS, GLS, and quantile regression models with full inference
Build generalized linear models (logistic, Poisson, Gamma regressions)
Analyze time series with ARIMA, SARIMAX, and exponential smoothing
Estimate discrete choice models (binary, multinomial, count data)
Run comprehensive diagnostic tests (heteroskedasticity, normality, autocorrelation)
Generate publication-ready coefficient tables and statistical summaries
limitations: Requires user to prepare data in pandas DataFrames
Does not include automated model selection (manual specification required)
No built-in visualization - requires matplotlib integration
May require statistical knowledge for appropriate model selection

use_cases.title: Regression analysis
use_cases.description: Fit linear and generalized linear models with robust standard errors and diagnostic testing

use_cases.title: Econometric modeling
use_cases.description: Estimate causal effects with proper inference, hypothesis testing, and model comparison

use_cases.title: Time series forecasting
use_cases.description: Build ARIMA models for forecasting with confidence intervals and residual diagnostics

prompt_templates.title: Basic regression
prompt_templates.prompt: Fit an OLS regression model using statsmodels with robust standard errors. Show the coefficient summary and test for heteroskedasticity.

prompt_templates.title: Logistic regression
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a logistic regression model for a binary outcome. Calculate odds ratios, marginal effects, and classification metrics.

prompt_templates.title: Time series
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze this time series data with ARIMA. Check stationarity, identify model order, fit the model, and generate 12-step forecasts with prediction intervals.

prompt_templates.title: Model comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare several model specifications using AIC, BIC, and likelihood ratio tests. Recommend the best model with justification.

output_examples.input: Fit an OLS model with robust standard errors and show key diagnostics

best_practices: Always add constant with sm.add_constant() unless excluding intercept deliberately
Test model assumptions (heteroskedasticity, normality, autocorrelation) after fitting
Use robust standard errors (HC0-HC3) when assumption violations are detected
Report confidence intervals alongside point estimates for inference
anti_patterns: Forgetting to add constant leads to biased intercept estimates
Using OLS for binary outcomes produces incorrect probabilities
Not checking for influential observations before interpretation

faq.question: What is the difference between OLS and GLM?
faq.answer: OLS assumes normally distributed errors with constant variance. GLM extends this to non-normal outcomes using different distributions and link functions.

faq.question: How do I choose between Logit and Probit?
faq.answer: Both work similarly for binary outcomes. Logit has fatter tails. Use Logit for easier interpretation (odds ratios) or Probit for theoretical reasons.

faq.question: What order should I use for ARIMA?
faq.answer: Use ACF/PACF plots to identify p (AR order) and q (MA order). Use ADF test for stationarity to determine d (differencing).

faq.question: When should I use robust standard errors?
faq.answer: Use robust SEs when heteroskedasticity is present or when there's clustering in the data that induces correlation.

faq.question: How do I compare nested models?
faq.answer: Use likelihood ratio test. For non-nested models, compare AIC or BIC values. Lower AIC/BIC indicates better fit.

faq.question: What diagnostic tests should I run after fitting?
faq.answer: Test heteroskedasticity (Breusch-Pagan), normality (Jarque-Bera), autocorrelation (Durbin-Watson), and check influential observations (Cook's distance).
